boardgame.name: Control Tower: LAX Airport
Torre de Control: Aeropuerto LAX
boardgame.description:
From the designer:

Control Tower: LAX Airport is a family boardgame about the management of the planes in an airport.
The players are air controllers who must land and take off the planes and distribute those planes in the diferent areas of the airport like repair/maintenance garage or refuelling to satisfice their requeriments.

The game is based on Control Tower with new mechanism.
The players share the LAX Airport while in Control Tower each player manage his own airport. This change makes different feelings between both games.

Control Tower: LAX Airport is an addictive boargame for 2 to 5 players, with easy rules but complex making decisions.

From the designer (Spanish):

"Torre de Control" es un juego de mesa familiar sobre la gestión de aviones en un aeropuerto.
Los jugadores encarnan a controladores aéreos de la gestión interna de un aeropuerto y entre sus funciones están ordenar los aterrizajes y despegues de los aviones y las distribución de los aviones en los diferentes servicios del aeropuerto tales como repostaje y reparación y mantenimiento.

El juego esta basado en "Torre de Control" pero con nuevas mecánicas. En esta versión los jugadores tienen un único aeropuerto común a diferencia de la anterior versión que cada jugador tenia el suyo propio. Este cambio hace que ambas versiones transmitan unas sensaciones de juego totalmente diferentes.

"Torre de control: Aeropuerto LAX" es un juego adictivo de 2 a 5 jugadores, de reglas muy sencillas pero con mucha toma de decisiones.

boardgame.name: Dungeon Saga: Compendio dell'Avventuriero
Dungeon Saga: Le Compagnon de l'Aventurier
Dungeon Saga: The Adventurer's Companion
boardgame.description:
Like Madriga and her companions, your adventures do not stop with the end of the Dwarf King’s Quest. Mantica teems with dark places, great treasures and evil deeds, and this book will help you to construct your own adventures amongst them, whether you wish to create a hero to battle the darkness, or your own villain to rule the world.

Features:

Create a hero - Generate a truly individual Hero or Overlord from scratch, based on any model in your collection. The choice is yours, from name and profession to spells and songs!

Design the Dungeon - Conjure up your very own maps, objectives and backstory. From the cavernous to the claustrophobic, we give you the tools and tips to put together a unique challenge.

Level Up - Watch proudly as your Character evolves from the very first adventure, gaining levels, abilities, and above all great stories to tell! Will you master a discipline, or branch out and learn new skills?

Be Bad - Turn the game on its head by playing as an evil party, heading off to take down a ‘good’ Overlord and his band of so-called Heroes.

Explore - Between adventures, visit one of 13 different downtime locations to rest, replenish and more! Will it be Tavern or the Temple this time?

Play Solo or Full Co-op - These rules allow for a new and engaging single-player experience, in addition to a co-operative mode in which no Overlord player is required!

Tackle Uncharted Dungeons - Venture into the unknown and hold your breath as the map unfolds before you in this exciting variant where no-one knows what lurks around the next corner!

Your Dungeon Saga Awaits you...

boardgame.name: The Perilous Secrets of Wilford Manor
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Perilous Secrets of Wilford Manor is First Volume of the Doombringer Saga Campaign Arc. This adventure module that can be used in any D&D 4e Campaign Setting.

"My son, Tulwen, with whom some of you are acquainted, has gone... missing," he states flatly, his deep voice low and tense. "I fear something may have happened to him, for he is nearly a week overdue in returning."

The Earl fixes you with a sad stare and says, "I would require... no, I ask you, as Tulwen's friend... to go and find out what happened to my son."

Something strange is happening in the sleepy hamlet of Wilford. No one at court has heard from the Baron in years. And now the young knight, Tulwen, sent to investigate is long overdue. A powerful Earl has sent you to find his son, which would seem a simple quest, but there is so much more to The Perilous Secrets of Wilford Manor.

The Doombringer Saga is a series of adventure modules designed as an entire campaign arc for Player-Characters from Level 1 to Level 30. Although the First Volume is created for the beginning of the Heroic Tier, the adventure is epic in scope. It will introduce Player-Characters to a world-shaking threat which will not only decide the fate of the Mundane Realm, but that of the Feyweald and Shadowmoor as well!

The Perilous Secrets of Wilford Manor Includes:

An engaging storyline that can be played as part of the Doombringer Saga Campaign Arc, or as a stand-alone adventure for five 1st Level Characters.
A back story complete with adventure "hooks" to introduce Characters to The Doombringer Saga.
8 Challenging Combat Encounters
3 Unique Skill Challenges
Nearly a dozen full color tactical encounter maps
New Monsters, Hazards, and More!

boardgame.name: Invocation Frontiers
boardgame.description:
Real-time game, in which up to 6 players must simultaneously and continuously play cards to its own boards trying to defeat at least one of the different powers of any of the opponent's cards and take them. The effects of the played cards are instantaneous and change the powers and abilities of other cards in play.

It's a fast and frenetic game, that can be played even with kids.
The game is played in rounds until the deck is empty (more players means less time). When this happens, the players count the total strength of the defeated cards, and who has more is declared winner.
It can also be played in constructed deck mode.

boardgame.name: A Curious Deck for Extraordinary Liars
boardgame.description:
This is the first of a series of games based on some simple rules... Here's the description from the back of the box:

A Curious Deck for Extraordinary Liars contains 56 peculiar cards depicting surreal and unintentionally hilarious Victorian art from ads and postcards dated 1880-1910.

Instructions for play:
The first player takes a card from the deck. The card holder may choose to describe what they see on the card or lie about what is on the card. It's up to the other players to determine whether the card holder is lying or telling the truth. Players are permitted to ask questions.

When all players have guessed Lie or Truth, the card holder announces the correct answer and reveals the card.

The player to the left then takes a new card from the deck and continues the game.

Players who guess correctly get 1 point.

The first player to 10 points wins.

boardgame.name: Mother Truckers
boardgame.description:
Mother Truckers is a CB jaw-jackin', blacktop fast-trackin', madcap dash across 1970s America for 2-4 players. The goal of the game is for your female trucker to make a name for herself by being the first to gain 12 Fame Points and show the boys you can outhaul, outdrive, and outwit every other gearjammer on the road. Put the hammer down as you pick up Commodities and deliver them to cities that demand them for Fame. Earn Action cards for your accomplishments and use them to dominate the highway as you become a truck driving legend! Just be sure to steer clear of old smokey...

On each turn, a player rolls the Movement Die and optionally the Speeding Die if they wish to attempt speeding. Speeding can allow for an extra Movement point per turn, but can cause wasted fuel trying to avoid the cops if they catch you.

The player may then split their Movement between physically moving road spaces on the map, refueling, and picking up or dropping off loads in cities. Each road space costs 10% fuel and players are towed to the connected city of another player's choice if they run out of fuel.

Contracts offer incentives to deliver certain types of goods or travel to specific regions for bonus Fame. Action cards spice up the game by creating risky scenarios for extra Fame such as Bar Brawls and Street Chicken. Or, play devious deeds against your opponents such as shooting out their gas tanks and stealing their loads. Naturally, all cards are flavored with classic 1970s CB jargon.

boardgame.name: Palette Swap
boardgame.description:
Palette Swap is a 2-4 player logic puzzle game in which you are given a 'palette' of primary colors that you mix, match, and swap with your fellow artists in order to complete your schemes to win the game. If you're clever you can complete multiple schemes in a single turn, and close attention is rewarded if another artist creates the scheme you were after when it's not your turn.

On your turn, you may spend two of the five colors in your palette for their effects. Red allows you to match the colors your opponents have, yellow lets you mix your colors and theirs together, and blue lets you swap a color from your palette with one of another player's colors. Playing two primary colors gets you a secondary color, which simply combines the effects of the two primaries. Playing two secondary colors get you a black, which you must use on your next turn and costs you your secondary colors.

As you change the colors you possess and your opponent's, you will be able to complete your goals, all of which are based on actual color schemes such as split complimentary and analogous schemes. Accomplishing all five of your schemes first makes you the victor.

The game also includes cooperative rules for playing with younger children and rules for solo play.

boardgame.name: Pokémon Moon
Pokémon Sun
Pokémon Sun and Moon
Poketto Monsutā San & Mūn
ポケットモンスター サン・ムーン
boardgame.description:
Pokémon Sun and Pokémon Moon (ポケットモンスター　サン・ムーン Poketto Monsutā San & Mūn?) are role-playing video games developed by Game Freak and published by Nintendo for the Nintendo 3DS. They are the first installments in the seventh generation of Pokémon games. First announced in February 2016 through a special Nintendo Direct, both Sun and Moon were released worldwide in November 2016, commemorating the franchise's 20th anniversary.

As with previous installments, each game follows the journey of a young Pokémon trainer (and the trainer's friends) as they train Pokémon. This time, the game takes place in the Alola region—based on Hawaii—with the object of the game being to thwart the schemes of the nefarious criminal organization Team Skull, all while attempting to challenge various Pokémon trainers of gradually increasing difficulty. Sun and Moon introduced 81 new Pokémon species, and includes new features such as Alolan forms of previous generation Pokémon, powerful moves known as Z-Moves, new, powerful creatures known as Ultra Beasts, updated battle and training mechanics, and improved polygonal 3D graphics. The games also adopted the previously introduced battle mechanic known as Mega Evolution, which was first introduced in Pokémon X and Y. Although Sun and Moon are mostly independent of each other, both feature largely the same plot, and while either can be played separately, trading Pokémon between the two games is allowed.

Upon release, the game received positive reviews from critics, and shipped over 10 million units worldwide within a week, becoming one of the fastest selling games in Nintendo's history. With 14.69 million copies sold worldwide by the end of December 2016, Sun and Moon are the third-best-selling Nintendo 3DS titles.

Source: Wikipedia, "Pokémon Sun and Moon", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Snow Day!
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Snow Day! is a rules-light, lighthearted, primarily narrative game. Characters are children exploring an ephemeral winter wonderland that freakishly occurs in Hawaii. Characters are defined by a single Attribute: Age. Action resolution uses a single d20 roll. The game supports two categories of actions - Fantasy Actions and Reality Actions. To succeed on a Fantasy Action, the d20 roll must be equal to or less than Age; to succeed on a Reality Action, the d20 roll must be equal to or greater than Age. Much of the game revolves around the construction of fantasy snow monsters, imbued with fantastic capabilities.

boardgame.name: Stockpile: Continuing Corruption
스탁파일: 계속되는 부패
boardgame.description:
Description from the publisher:

Stockpile: Continuing Corruption, the first expansion for Stockpile, the critically acclaimed stock market game of insider trading, contains four expansion modules that can be played separately or used all together for more strategic game play.

Module 1: Forecast Dice — Six custom dice offer more excitement by changing the market forecast round-to-round. Roll the dice at the beginning of the round and select the appropriate forecast cards. The dice cause the market to rise or fall on any given turn and ensures that no two games will ever be the same.

Module 2: Bonds — Bond Cards present a new, safe investment option for players. Purchasing bonds can provide a steady stream of interest payments every round. However, it comes at a price. The original money used to purchase bonds cannot be recovered until the end of the game. Be careful not to overspend or you might lose out on valuable stockpiles.

Module 3: Commodities & Taxes — Commodities & Taxes create much more tension during the game. Each round, players add Commodity or Tax Cards face-up to the stockpiles. Collect different types of commodities and dodge taxes to earn substantial end-game bonuses.

Module 4: More Investors — Stockpile: Continuing Corruption adds six new investors from around the world who have heard about massive profits being made, and they want in on the action. Each investor possesses a unique ability that opens up more ways to win.

boardgame.name: Thirty Six: 36 Stratagems
boardgame.description:
Strategy and conquest in Ming Dynasty China

36 stratagems is a game for 2-3 players, which is set in the Ming Dynasty era in China and neighbouring states. You are the leader of one of several rival families aspiring to become emperor of the entire region. You start the game in a capital city, with just an aspiring emperor, a scout and a small army. The aim of the game is to become the dominant dynasty by conquering and maintaining control of capitals, temples and prefectures. Each of these actions will help you in gaining the victory points needed to be the undisputed emperor and win the game. To be successful you will need to manage your budding empire carefully. Manage your economy through taxation and expanding your population, secure stability by maintaining cohesion among the political elite, maintain a strong military through recruitment of units supported by powerful generals and avoid rebellion by gaining popularity with your subjects. You face an uncertain destiny and will encounter many challenges during your reign including plague, piracy and looting. However, you are not alone in your quest, as to help you gain the power you so richly deserve and to undermine your pitiful and unworthy enemies, you can call upon the ancient Chinese wisdom enshrined in the 36 stratagems.

Sandy Petersen’s Cthulhu Mythos is the most comprehensive guide to including Lovecraftian elements in your Pathfinder Roleplaying game, written by the author of the groundbreaking Call of Cthulhu RPG, and developed primarily by James Jacobs (creative director of Paizo) and David N. Ross.

boardgame.name: Tetris 2 + Bombliss
Tetris 2/ Bombliss
boardgame.description:
User Summary

As the title would suggest, the game features both standard Tetris as well as another similar game called Bombliss. Tetris offers three game modes: standard marathon (A-type), start with garbage (B-type), and rising garbage (C-type). There is also a two-player versus mode where clearing rows sends garbage to the other player.

Bombliss is slightly different from normal Tetris. Arranged on the board and in some dropped pieces are bomb squares. Completing a row does not clear the blocks in the row, but will trigger any bombs in the row which will destroy blocks. Different sizes of bombs will generate larger explosions. Bombliss is offered in standard marathon mode, a puzzle mode where a set board must be cleared using set piece drops, and a 2-player versus mode.

boardgame.name: Lich
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A lich is an undead creature, typically a spell caster of some type that has who has used its magical powers to unnaturally extend its life. But not all lichs are the same.

How old are they? What species are they? Why did they become a lich in the first place?

All these aspects and more are covered in this volume of the CDG. The CDG (Creature Description Generator) range is designed with a fantasy setting in mind, but can easily be used for sci-fi or modern/horror settings.

The aspects covered:

Age - What is the apparent age of the Lich? At what age where they transformed into a member of the undead?
Condition - Lichs can range from being almost living, to virtual skeletons and this aspect gives you a few suggestions as to what that condition may be.
Death - When they became a lich, they had to die or have something similar to death applied to them. How did this occur
Lair - Where does the lich call home? Is it a grand castle or do they dwell in a cave behind a waterfall?
Personality - What sort of personality does the lich have? Are they, for a lich, kind or cruel and uncaring?
Phylactery - The phylactery is one of the hallmarks of a lich as it can house their soul or power source. What is the nature of this vessel?
Reason - Why did they become a lich in the first place? Was it through choice or was this state of undeath forced upon them from an angry god?
Servants & Minions - Does the lich any servants to add it or minion to boss around and do its bidding?
Species - The majority of lichs seem to be human males for some reason, but other species have found the path to lichdom as well, sometimes through choice. What species does the lich belong to?
Quirks & Features - Not all lichs are the same. Many have unique quirks and features that help stand out and be more memorable. Roll once on this table to find out what that can be. It might be something about the lichs phylactery, the fact they are female pretending to be male or something else entirely.

boardgame.name: Mastermind's Workshop
boardgame.description:
New Year, New Challenge!

Each year the greatest gnome tinkerer, Mastermind, takes on a new apprentice. Becoming this apprentice is a most coveted position, bringing with it the chance to learn skills and techniques that most only dream of; not to mention the prestigious work afterward. You will play as an up-and-coming gnomish tinkerer fighting for your place as Mastermind’s protégé at this year’s competition. Mastermind chooses this apprentice each year by their ability to finish a single task. It will be your job to destroy a Masterbot; a steamwork contraption Mastermind has designed and built to attack your workshop.



Play

Each player receives a game board, a player placard for tracking resources, a gnome character, and a starter bot they can build to help defend their workshop from Masterminds Masterbot.
Players take turns playing their characters and Mastermind. On Mastermind’s turn all the players decide the actions of the Masterbot attacking the player to their left , while the players attempt to defend their workshop from destruction. On the players turn dice are rolled to gather resources. Bots are then bought, scrapped, or built. If a bot has been built, the player then has the option to attack and try to take out Mastermind’s machine.



Objective

Players must succeed in destroying their assigned Masterbot before the competition can destroy theirs. Sounds easy enough, but the other competitors will try to sabotage you at every turn even while trying to destroy their Masterbots.

boardgame.name: Divine Hunters
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Deities, taken as a group, value their followers like a devil values souls. That is, followers are essentially currency and power for those with the divine spark. Unfortunately for most deities, followers possess free will; nothing gets in the way more of the best-laid plans. Most times when a true believer strays, a simple atonement spell — typically coupled with a suitable quest — is enough to steer things back toward the deity’s favor. Sometimes, though, the offense is so severe an atonement spell just isn’t enough. Some offenses are so severe, so drastic, that forgiveness is nigh impossible. The only recourse in these circumstances is to dole out swift and severe punishment. Most of the time, deities are loath to interact directly with mortals. To handle these special circumstances, they have an unusual breed of hunters called the nel’barzoth. Divine Hunters presents four new monsters, including a CR 22 mythic version, to hunt your infidels; it also presents the GM with rules for creating new versions.

boardgame.name: Doolhof Twist
Doolhof: Twist
Labyrinthe Twist
Twist Labyrinth
Das verdrehte Labyrinth
boardgame.description:
The labyrinth in the magic garden is constantly changing. By clever rotating the magical hedges, players open new paths to mysterious creatures and precious treasures. Magic cards help to fulfill the tasks. Who masters the turns and finds his way out of the magic garden first?

A new twist at the changing labyrinth. This time, the paths are bordered by hedges, which can be rotated to change the paths.

Each player has a stack of cards that direct him to various places in the labyrinth. In his turn, the player moves his pawn along the path; he may also rotate one hedge before, during or after his move. If he reaches his current target, he turns his next target card face up. Otherwise, he gets a magic card as consolation.

The magic cards can be used during a players turn to aid movement. A hole allows to slip through a hedge. Two fairies allow to fly from one fairy spot to another one, ignoring the terrain in between. A player may use any number of magic cards in his turn.

After a player has visited the targets on his six cards, the other players decide which exit he needs to reach to win the game.

boardgame.name: The Brotherhood (2004)
boardgame.description:
User summary:

This game, submitted in several posts to an online competition forum, is a fusion of a particular setting with a fairly lightweight rules system. The setting is a typical fantasy world, but one in which good has lost and evil triumphed. But the evil has subsequently become listless and without energy, yielding an overwhelmingly negative but banal existence. The characters - members of The Brotherhood adventure within this setting. Characters have basic attributes and several spell-like powers. Action resolution uses a d6 minus a d6, yielding a -5 to +5 spread that compares to a target difficulty. The dice must be of identified colors.

The game is ambitious and includes a brief bestiary and some advice for game masters. However, the rules are fairly subtle and probably would require an experience game master.

boardgame.name: Barely Balanced
boardgame.description:
Barely Balanced is a quick game of daredevil antics and reckless stupidity in which you try to create an acrobatic show that would strike fear into the hearts of insurance adjusters everywhere.

Game play - Each round players start with a hand of 6 cards. The goal is to play tricks using the cards in their hand. Players my trade cards from the table or draw more cards from the deck. The player to play all their cards take the round, but all the tricks played by everyone are scored. Once a single player has taken 3 round the game ends. The player who has scored the most points over the course of the total rounds wins the game.

Game play was influenced by French Tarot and Japaneses Hanafuda and other classic card games.

The Barely Balanced card game is based on the Comedic/Acrobatic stunt show Barely Balanced.

Barely Balanced game was designed as promotional product for the group by designer Max Holliday. Max had been a fan of the acrobatic group for a few years, and while watching a show at the Bristal Ren Fair came up with the game. He proposed the game as soon as the show ended.
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Barely Balanced: The Stunt Stacking Game – Troublemakers Expansion

Following the huge successes of the number 1 Steam top selling epic SRPG, Agarest: Generations of War and its prequel Agarest: Generations of War ZERO, Ghostlight are proud to release the massively updated sequel to the series, Agarest: Generations Of War 2!

boardgame.name: Legends of the Mist
boardgame.description:
Description from the publisher:

Amallian was an amazing kingdom, with lush forests, amazing coasts, cuddly martial artists, and the best Emperor known. The one downside of living there was the constant infighting of the clans. They not only disagreed about the way the empire was built, but the way they traded with their neighbors, too.

The clans didn't agree on much, but the Emperor decreed that there was to be no open fighting amongst them. This "peace" lasted for many years. Then came the storm of all storms. Sweeping many clans away, the Emperor was lost for solutions — but then in the Osae Valley, a mist had appeared, and those who entered it were transported to a new land. The Emperor decreed that all clans should venture forth and settle their new empire.

As they did, the oversight was little to none...which lead to the clans competing for the favor of the Emperor by any means necessary. Now the clans of Amallian race to win the favor of the Emperor by building her Empire, trading goods, and showing the most strength on the other side!

In Legends of the Mist, you take on the role of a legend from one of the four clans. By rolling dice from your pool, you can work to build the Emperor's new kingdom with new plots, fight to control them, produce goods from them, and gain wealth for your clan and the kingdom. Each die type has a different frequency of letting you perform these actions. The other clans will work to undermine you every now and again and since dice are assigned in secret, your planning and foresight are important.

Should you complete the objectives that the Empress gave you better than anyone else, you will be rewarded as the winner of her favor!

Characters are all samurai that have three Facets (Attributes): Awar, Kenjutsu, and Tanka. Each Facet has a numeric value, distributed from a point pool. This represents the dice pool associated with that Facet. Opposed actions utilize opposed dice pool rolls where successes are counted and compared.

The game has an interesting structure of basic rules augmented by several optional rules, allowing groups to utilize as much or as little rules complexity as desired. The game was published in a series of forum posts, but a final "gathered" post puts all the pieces together with some clarifications and better flow. Additionally, the game subsequently was published in formatted HTML on the author's personal site (no longer extant).

boardgame.name: Merchants of Medieval Europe
boardgame.description:
Introduction
Gamble your family’s coin in search of emerging riches! Buy and sell goods at the whim of a wild market that will keep you guessing and laughing with wonder! Will you make your fortune on one big deal or diversify your goods and strike smartly?
Carry silk, wine, spice, and more on your wagon throughout medieval Europe. Borrow funds from the Merchant Bank and accept contracts from wealthy nobles to afford and deliver these prized crates for extra rewards.
By the end of the year, will you return home as a wealthy winner or a penniless peasant?
Merchants of Medieval Europe is a 3-6 player game designed for casual gamers and families.​


Winning the Game
At the end of the last round, the player with the most coin wins. Subtract from scores if players have uncompleted contracts and/or debt.

Length of Game
The standard game lasts 12 rounds. Exhaust the Market Deck once for one standard game. Lengthen the game in 12 round increments if you
prefer a longer experience.

Setup
1. Place the market good tracker discs on the numbers located around the board’s Perimeter Market matching the Initial Value chart above.
2. Shuffle the contract cards and make the contract deck. Shuffle the market cards and create the Market deck by drawing 12 cards. Place the remaining market cards back in the game box.
3. Separate the 8 colored good cards and create the Resource Supply by placing all of them next to the board along with all the coin and Banknotes. This is the Merchant Bank of Europe.
4. Each player takes 1 horse mat (one horse side face up), one color matching pawn, and 15 coin.
5. Each player draws 4 Contract cards, chooses 1, and places their pawn on the Contract’s delivery location. Return the Contract cards to the deck and shuffle the deck.
6. The player who traveled the farthest away in the last week is the first player. Play continues clockwise from the first player.

Gameplay
1. Market Phase

i. The first player flips a market card and places it on top of a market discard deck.
ii. Players adjust the Perimeter Market good trackers to their new values dictated by the drawn market card.


2. Accounting Phase

i. Players can upgrade their wagon to two horses.
ii. Players can take 1 debt banknote.
iii. Players can pay back any amount of debt banknotes.


3. Action Phase

i. The first player begins their turn and takes up to 4 actions.

a. End their turn by adjusting the Perimeter Market based on their buys/sells, +1 for buys and -1 for sells.



ii. The Action Phase continues clockwise until every player takes up to 4 actions and ends their turn.


4. Round Ends

Action Phase
Take up to 4 actions per turn in any order and you can repeat any particular action any number of times until you run out of actions.
A. Move- Earn movement points from your wagon and move your pawn. 1 movement point allows movement from one region into an adjacent region.
B. Buy- Buy as many goods as you can afford from the resources stockpile, so long as you are in a region that sells the desired good, the good is in stock, and you have room in your wagon.
C. Trade- Buy, sell, or trade goods with another player in the same colored territory as your pawn.
D. Sell- From any region, you can sell any number of goods back to the stockpile for the current market value as dictated by the Perimeter Market.
E. Contracts- Accept a contract by drawing 4 contract cards, choosing 1, and discarding the remaining cards. Alternatively, complete a contract at the written destination with the required goods.

boardgame.name: H.E.A.D. Hunters: Starter Pack
boardgame.description:
H.E.A.D. Hunters is a card-driven miniatures game for two or more players. Each player controls their own 5.25" Hero of Every Age & Dimension (H.E.A.D.) Hunter Toy that stores all the components of the game in its head. Inside each H.E.A.D. Hunter is its own themed deck of cards, battle bases, measuring string and combat dice.

The starter pack includes Erik Thanessen (Viking) & Xeno X9 (Robot). Cards from other H.E.A.D. Hunters can be mixed and matched to customize the player's deck, matching their own play style.

Each character has a unique set of starting terrain as part of their deck that can be placed in a multitude of positions and layouts to create unlimited fields of battle. Once these are placed, the players draw and play cards to attack and defend against other Hunters as they move their toy around the table for position and opportunity; where you attack from is as important as what you attack with!

Game play continues until one Hunter is left standing, but be warned: As players take and inflict damage, unique character abilities are enabled which can turn the tide of the game. When the game is over, all the components fit back inside the head while the toy sits patiently (and attractively) on your shelf, waiting for its next opponent.

boardgame.name: Einer freut sich immer
boardgame.description:
Each player has a set of four pawns that start in his or her side of the board. The goal is to move the pawns around the board to the "Ziel" section. Movement is determined by a die. All players move clockwise around the same board, so they may capture each others pawns. Whenever a pawn arrives on a space as the result of a die-roll, it advances by the number of spaces shown on that space. If a pawn arrives on a red space, it advances into an inner ring. The pawns have to circle the innermost ring, till they manage to enter their "Ziel" section. Captured pawns are returned to their player's "Start" section. The winner is the first player to move all pawns into the "Ziel" section.
This game was published about 1930.

boardgame.name: Ecken-Schreck!
boardgame.description:
The players have to move their pawn from the starting point to one of the yellow or red spaces in the center of the game board. The red and yellow dice determine movement on the game track, while the green symbol die controls movement on the checkered center section by one or two spaces each turn. The results of the yellow and red dice are translated by each player's dice result card. Possible outcomes are forward movement (V), backward movement (Z) or no movement at all (Symbol).

The Corner spaces have the following meanings:
V - move forward to the next red triangle
Z - move backward to the last yellow triangle
Symbol - miss your next turn
black spot - return to the black starting space

The game was likely published in the 1920s.

boardgame.name: Children of the North: Assault on the Frozen Isle of the Lich-Lord
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Characters in this rules-light game are defined by a concise narrative statement. They also have a single Attribute with a value from 1-10, selected by player fiat. This Attribute describes the character's "evil vs. good" axis, with a 1 being a "very good" character and a 10 being a "very evil" character, but one not so evil as to be reviled by the other characters. Action resolution uses a single d10 roll with results varying for characters depending on their Attribute and the type of action they are attempting. The game master determines whether the action is good or evil or somewhere in between.

The game is intended to explore the nature of good vs. evil, though it provides no suggestion of what might be meant by these terms. The game does use a credible mechanism for assembling the adventuring party from disparate individuals who may be antipathetic to each other.

boardgame.name: Catacombs
Catacombs (Third Edition)
Katakomben
boardgame.description:
Catacombs is an award-winning, cooperative board game set in the fantasy world of Cimathue, and you need skill and dexterity to master this fast-paced game.

One player (the Overseer) marshals an army of monsters while the others choose from six brave heroes who embark on a quest to save the town of Stormtryne from the threat lurking in the catacombs below. As the heroes explore, they must use their abilities, buy items, and recruit allies to help them defeat the monsters before facing the powerful Catacomb Lord, thereby saving the town.

In more detail, in Catacombs players flick wooden discs that represent the monsters and heroes. Contact with an opposing piece inflicts damage, while missiles, spells, and other special abilities can cause other effects. When all of the monsters of a room have been cleared, the heroes can move further into the catacomb.

Items and equipment upgrades can be purchased from the Merchant with gold taken from fallen monsters. The Catacomb Lord is the final danger that the heroes must defeat to win the game. Conversely, the Overseer wins if all of the heroes are defeated.

This third edition of Catacombs has all-new artwork compared to the earlier editions, but more importantly the keywords from the first two editions has been replace with iconography, the terminology has changed, and the third edition has new shot types, new card effects, and a different set of components (many of which have changed statistics) as well as wall pieces not present in earlier editions.

boardgame.name: Monster Hunter Academy
boardgame.description:
A monstrous board game encouraging kids & families to have imaginative fun with game play imaginative interaction!

A classic dungeon setting is the backdrop as players assume the roles of tough hunters bound and determined to do three things: to defeat as many monsters as possible, to collect treasure, and to make it out unscathed.

Players become bona fide monster hunters as they delve into dungeons filled with beasts and obstacles. At the beginning of each session, players choose one of three game modes in which they will compete. Treasure Hunt, Monster Hunt, or Dungeon Escape.

At the beginning of each session, players choose one of three game modes in which they will compete:

Treasure Hunt – Be the first to get to the treasure

Monster Hunt – Defeat all the monsters on the board, player with the most captured wins

Dungeon Escape – Be the first player to get to the finish exit

Up to 4 boards can be arranged in numerous ways based on the number of players. Obstacle tiles including corridors, pits, locked doors, and secret doors are added to the boards. The number depends on the game mode being played. Monsters are then added to the board.

Each player rolls a d10 for movement through squares that make up the dungeon boards. When they get to obstacles they must make an extra roll to get past them. Sometimes loosing a turn, or having to turn around and find another path. When players encounter monsters they must reference the Monster's card to see how to defeat them. Examples are an opposing roll of the the die, rolling an odd number, rolling 7 or higher.

boardgame.name: DETHRONED: The Real-Time Combat Card Game
boardgame.description:
DETHRONED is what happens when a game developer is forced to play too much Mafia. DETHRONED takes the hidden-role genre and makes it faster, giving the power to kill in YOUR HANDS.

Simple enough for parties, meta enough for board game geeks.

A dynamic card game fusing Real-Time combat with the hidden-role genre.

No turns. No waiting. Just lies and murder!

DETHRONED, the whole game is a set that comes with 2 decks:
-Traitors and Kings & Guards and Thieves-

Each with their own theme, unique art, and lore. They can be played completely independently up to 4, OR together for up to 8 player chaos and fun!

Players first begin by going around the table claiming a role. Depending on the role you secretly got will help determine if you should lie about your role, though you never have to. After that, players continue discussing until 2 players vote to begin combat.

Once combat begins, players may attack each other at any point in time, until someone dies. Every time someone dies, combat is paused and a vote to end the game goes up. All living players must unanimously vote to end and to not vote yes, you have to attack another player, if you cannot then you're forced to vote yes to end. The game can only end in a stalemate (players reveal hands to prove such) OR after a player has died.

Once the game ends, roles are revealed and winners are determined based on the role's win conditions.

DETHRONED RULEBOOK: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xCcO5ec94KChMHVhbrJRWvij...

boardgame.name: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies Strategy Battle Game
boardgame.description:
The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey Strategy Battle Game is the tabletop game for two or more players. This free PDF expansion is packed with supplemental rules which enable you to recreate the thrilling events of The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies™ with your collection of Citadel miniatures.

This expansion includes two exciting new scenarios that recreate the pivotal events of The Hobbit: The Battle of Five Armies, allowing you to join in the adventure as Thorin’s Company concludes its quest to reclaim Erebor.

This PDF includes profiles and rules for a host of new Citadel miniatures allowing you to play games with our favorite heroes and villains from The Hobbit: The Battle of Five Armies, from the great and terrible dragon, Smaug, to the mighty heroes of the Free Peoples that form the heart of the White Council.

The updated army lists enable you to field the warring hosts that fought in the climactic Battle of Five Armies on the tabletop, from the valiant survivors of Smaug’s attack on Lake-town to the majestic Elven host led by Thranduil, King of Mirkwood.

Stealth and Steel

Don't Follow the Lights!

Inside, you'll find 18 richly crafted map tiles, including:

- Boggy Crossroads
- Backwater Island
- Embankment
- Eroded Path
- Mossy Curve
- Sediment Crescent

Game Masters shouldn't waste their time sketching maps whenever characters explore a treacherous marsh. With Pathfinder Map Pack: Marsh Trails, you'll always have dangers ready if the adventurers step off solid ground!

boardgame.name: Plague Inc.: The Board Game
boardgame.description:
Plague Inc: The Board Game is a strategic game of infection, evolution and extinction for 1-5* people - based on the smash-hit digital game with over 85 million players. Can you infect the world?

Each player is a deadly disease and they must battle against each other to spread their plagues, develop new symptoms and ultimately wipe out humanity.

Starting with Patient Zero, you spread your infection across the world by placing tokens in cities - earning DNA points and preventing other players from becoming dominant. Players choose which countries are placed on the board but you must be both climate resistant and connected to a country before you can infect it. Eventually, as countries become fully infected - you try to kill them using the Death Dice.

Each player’s unique pathogen can be upgraded by evolving trait cards onto an evolution slide (with DNA points). At the start, your disease is weak and unspecialised, so you will need to add new symptoms to make it stronger. Choose carefully and plan ahead in order to react to the changing world and exploit opportunities created by other player’s actions.

A simple nosebleed could accelerate things early on, whilst diarrhea will help you thrive in hot countries. Sneezing can infect new continents by air but Total Organ Failure would allow you wipe out multiple countries each turn.

As countries start to fall, use powerful event cards to alter the balance of power. You might try to eradicate a dominant player by bombing their diseased cities, or hold the Olympics to cause huge numbers of infected people to travel to a healthy continent.

boardgame.name: Torchbearer (2003)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Torchbearer, besides being a specific game with a setting, is a simple, flexible System that can be used for many different kinds of games. The next two Chapters describe the System in its entirety. Where I have described several different rule-options, the one that the default Torchbearer game uses will be listed
first.

User summary:

The rules set presented in this product is exceptionally difficult and recommended only for quite experience players. Nearly every rule is optional, and most rules have a few variants. Action resolution uses a complex mechanic based on levels of difficulty (a very simple Action Table, similar in concept to Fudge difficulty levels) compared to dice pool rolls using specialized dice (standard d6 can be used instead, however).

boardgame.name: A Slight Mistake: Players Book
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The Players Book provides a basic setting overview and rules for character creation. Characters have a complex variety of Attributes, placed into Attribute Groups. Characters also have Skills that can be improved through play. The game suggests characters select a type (roughly like a class in concept) to help define which Skills should be selected together, but this is not enforced by the rules. Skills are placed into Skill Groups though these primarily are organizational and not restrictive. Characters may also have a variety of feats, talents, and flaws (Traits) - including some which confer magical abilities.

The remainder of the volume includes the game mechanics, which are based on percentile rolls. The game is quite detailed with numerous rules for various special circumstances. There is a heavy focus on combat and the clear intent is to involve the characters in frequent person-to-person combat, highly favored over other styles of combat available in science fiction settings. Equipment lists, for example, include things like daggers and bows.

boardgame.name: Under the Overpass
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is a 16 x 30 inch Battlemap of a space Under an Overpass , it has Hex, Square and No Overlays, it also includes the VTT files for online play.

“We don’t know anything. Please just leave us alone.”—Paul

Under the Overpass is an exterior map of two support walls and nine columns for a highway above, a railway in the east, and an area in the west with three couches and a bed that are used by the homeless to sleep with the highway above sheltering them from the rain.

Under the Overpass is intended for use in modern or post-apocalyptic games (the scattered debris on the map gives it a ruined feel). It could even be a down on their luck superhero’s hideout.

Adventure hook for use with this map:

The People under the Overpass: A local gang has lost a drug shipment. Supposedly it was lost on a rail route. The gangers traced the drug shipment’s path by backtracking along the railway. They found a small community of homeless people next to the railway under the overpass. They questioned them, but they didn’t have any answers. The gang members didn’t like that and proceeded to beat on the spokesman of the homeless, Paul.

John, a member of the homeless community has an uncanny knack for knowing when the trains were coming. Almost like an internal clock. When Paul was attacked he threw himself at the gang members and tossed them on the railway into the way of an oncoming train. The result was two dead gang members and a call from the train operator to the police about the accident.

The player characters arrive on the scene as local law enforcement such as police or detectives. They are here to question the homeless. However, when he sees the cops, Paul runs for it. The gangers are angry about the death of their members and send a hit squad to kill the bums which arrive shortly after the cops chase after Paul or start their initial questioning of the homeless witnesses…

boardgame.name: Schnell ins Nest
boardgame.description: The players have to move their four cubes from the diagonaly opposite corner to the nest of their color. Movement to a neighboring space is achieved by tilting the cube by 90 degree, thereby changing the Image on the top of the cube. The movement can be continued in a straight line as Long as thre are unoccupied spaces. If two cubes are sitting next to or pass each other, the stronger image kills the weeker one (hunter - Fox - weasel - chicken - frog - gnat). The strongest Image is the hunter but he can be killed by the weakest, which is the gnat. Killed cubes are removed from the game. Cubes that have entered their own nest must show the correct animal on top to be saved. A saved animal counts 3 points and the cubes on the board of the last player count 2 points at the end of the game.

boardgame.name: Paper Quest
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Paper Quest is a rules-light storytelling game that uses a structured approach to generating an open-ended narrative. Traditionally, game play does not utilize a game master (though if the group prefers, one can be used). The action is driven by cards and resolution can be settled by the use of a simple dice roll. While any type of story can be told using the system, probably most will have some type of fairytale or fantastic qualities emerge.

One interesting aspect of the game allows for optional items to replace the pack of French playing cards as the narrative driver - noted options include dice, rune stones, Legos, "boogers", or even rocks.

boardgame.name: Extreme Assault
boardgame.description:
Players would first choose a pilot (difficulty) to be as, and then attempt to complete a set of missions in an operation area. The number of operations the player could do, depended on the difficulty, with the higher difficulties having more access; the number of operation areas in the game total around six. Each mission is often introduced by briefing with the player given information about what to expect, or what to destroy. Each operation area has a boss at the end that the player has to overcome.

During the course of the game, the player can find power-ups, ranging from ammo for the main guns, ammo for secondary weapons, or energy for the Sioux/T1's shields, and even pick up an extra gun for both vehicles' main weapons. Weapons range from a fast hitting "Razor" gun, a laser cannon, missiles, smart bombs, and more. Enemies ranged from helicopters, tanks, rocket buggies, flying robots, and stationary guns. Environments that the player deals with include wide open valleys, a volcanic island, a massive underground base, and the ice fields of Greenland complete with an alien city. The player often operates from the cockpit of the vehicle they are in, but can look around or even switch to 3rd person view.

Source: Wikipedia, "[en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extreme_Assault Extreme Assault]", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Patchwork (2015)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The three games in this collection grew out of different interests and odd turns taken by conversations with friends. Pilgrimage has multiple roots, ranging from The Canterbury Tales to a battered copy of James White’s Dream Millennium my parents picked up for me at a yard sale when I was a kid to chats with Johanna Haas about doodling and Silas de Marques Lima about games and therapy. Pine Grove owes its origins to Facebook and the radically different ways in which old friends remember our hometown. Saturday Knights is an ode to the attic in an old Victorian house where we played games when I was in high school, and the strange temptations and distractions that lurked beyond the game.

boardgame.name: Patchwork II (2016)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

As I was putting together these games I realized that in different ways each one deals with memory. Fall Lineup grew out of nostalgia. When we were kids we loved gimmicky shows like Automan and Small Wonder. Previews for Manimal captured our imaginations; my best friend was so terrified by them that he couldn’t go into a dark room for a month. A year or two ago we were talking about some of the shows and I realized that even though I could easily find clips online that seeing them again might ruin my memories of them.

The House of Unusual Size explores lost memories. Inspired by Gaston Bachelard’s The Poetics of Space, a version of the game originally appeared as part of the 2013 National Game Design Month 24-Hour RPG competition. Johanna Haas provided editorial and moral support when this came together during Thanksgiving, and the folks at Gaia House in Carbondale, Illinois, gave invaluable advice. Silas Marques de Lima deserves special praise for introducing the game to group therapy sessions for teens in São Paolo. His descriptions of their experiences inspired me to revisit the game.

Pen in Hand deals with a form of personal and social memory that evolved into a source for historians. I used to work as the director of a nineteenth-century house museum, and while doing research and reviews and I ran into repeated references to the autograph books kept by young women. The ways in which people used the books—and particularly the ways girls and young women used secret books to mark levels of connection—has fascinated me ever since.

User summary:

Cabell Manor presents a rules-light haunted house adventure. No game master is used; the players take turns creating a shared narrative experience. Play proceeds in turns. During each turn a player rolls the dice and narrates a segment of the adventure depending on the roll. Players also draw cards (from a custom deck) and respond to the events on the cards. The composition of the deck changes during game phases.

Note the card deck itself is provided as a print-and-play component of the game (and makes up the bulk of the document).

boardgame.name: Fantasy Stables: Regular Edition
boardgame.description:
In the game of Fantasy Stables you're trying to make it in the horse business. Your friends will now be your rivals as you compete to see who will end up on top. The object of the game is to collect the most money in cash, horse value and bonuses. Bonuses are awarded for collecting certain groups of horses. They add another level of strategy to the game. Game play is very easy and intuitive for horse people but no horse knowledge is needed to play.

Everyone begins the game with money and horses to start the fun right away. There are several suggested winning scenarios for you to choose from for one hour of play to days of fun. All the turns are cooperative but competitive to keep things lively!

Collect and show horse cards featuring fabulous pictures of real horses in 8 equestrian sports (Dressage, Driving, Trail, Western Pleasure, Western Performance, Racing, Cross Country and Hunter Jumper).

Add horses to your stable at public auctions where everyone can bid. Bid as high as you dare – you know the range but the horse’s actual value is kept a secret until the winning bid has been paid!
Everyone can enter the shows and choosing the right horse will give you an advantage but anyone could steal the win if luck is on their side.

There are random and yearly horse expenses to watch out for so manage your salary and show winnings well. All the players get a real-life horse job (vet, farrier, trainer etc.) who are paid the expenses to keep those interactive too!

Horses are unpredictable so you never know what will be around the corner – wins or losses!

boardgame.name: Mostly Evil
boardgame.description:
From their Evil Lairs / Parent's basement players rule Cityopolis by fear, defeating wave after wave of superheroes with their diabolical creations! Who will defeat the most heroes and rein supreme... from jail when they get caught because... well... Superheroes are awesome like that.

Players get a hand of cards from which they will play or discard 2 per turn. For example minions, like Florence 'Hard Nut' McGee, could be placed on the field and players can start to create fiendishly clever weapons like the Poisonous Death Lamp. Alternatively they could play event cards such as the "Publish a photo of your rival stroking a Kitten" to reduce the fear gripping the city. Finally they could get bored and call up a Superhero to help the city... Then later use them for target practise. Superheroes start a set distance from the City and move closer after every round. If they reach the city they start to reduce the fear count which acts as the game timer.

Reducing fear and calling up Superheroes nets players kudos worth VP's at the end but defeating Superheroes earns you Capes which are worth more VP's and after all you are Mostly Evil.

boardgame.name: Ice (2004)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Ice is a game of story telling, role playing, decision making, and resource management. When you play Ice, no matter your role in the game, your job is to entertain your fellows. Remember this. It will improve your gaming experience. In a game of Ice, one player is the referee and has a number of special duties. The other players are each primarily concerned with operating their character in the shared game world. Both the referee and the other players will sometimes: act "in character" when portraying the behavior of their characters, generate outcome statements during conflict resolution that will guide narration, describe scenes in which one or more player-character appear, provide input to any and all other players about each of these aspects of play or anything else -- typically in the form of "it would be cool if this happened" statements, and manage character resources primarily (but not solely) during conflict resolution. The referee's additional duties include: managing narration, adjudicating statement generation during conflict resolution, interpreting conflict outcomes, and awarding resources to the other players.

User summary:

Ice was partially developed under the working title Diamonds Are Forever; the title was change when the working title was used by another submission in the competition.

boardgame.name: Horizons
Horizonte
boardgame.description:
In Horizons, you are a starfaring species taking the first steps into a new galaxy. Find new stars, explore new worlds, collect valuable resources, and secure allies to gain the most ground in expanding your empire! Build colonies and resource collectors to hold onto control in various, and increasingly crowded, star systems. Do you have what it takes to manipulate the resources at your disposal and control the galaxy?!

How to win
The player with the most points wins the game.
Players score points by gaining knowledge, exploring new worlds, completing missions, and placing structures to gain majority control on each star system.
See the Scoring Side of your Scoring / Icon Player Aid cards for more information.

On Your Turn
Take 2 Actions: You may then take any 2 of the actions listed below. You may take the same action twice.
Explore: Draw and play a world from the bag. Take one knowledge.
Adapt: Activate a Habitat and/or take the top ally from any stack.
Build: Build a collector or colony.
Harvest: Gain 1 resource per collector you have built.
Conspire: Draw two mission cards or 1 Ally & 1 Mission card.

The game ends when a player places their last colony.

Score Victory Points for Controlling star systems, unspent knowledge, and completed Missions

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Whispers in the Door
boardgame.description:
A Snow From Korea Variation

From the introduction:

In Nihon, the summer is long, and dry, and hot, and all the men are abroad, seeking snow to cool the brows of their wives. But the courts are not silent; the halls are not still. The samurai ladies and the retainers of the daimyos are still about, weaving secrets.

The characters in Whispers in the Door are samurai ladies whose husbands and lords are abroad; in the absence of the men it falls to the wives to hold together the power of a clan, through deft manipulation of people, even men.

It is your job as a player to make sure your samurai retains the family's honour and assets, and to gather Secrets, which are the strongest avenue to power in the courts of Nihon.

boardgame.name: Four Walls and a Funeral
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The game presents a stark and bleak roleplaying setting of life in a prison. Characters have a Fight Points pool that decreases (only) during play. Characters also have and use a variety of coins during play, indicating things such as years of sentence, convictions, and reputation. While the characters may assist each other from time to time, they do son only in their own best interest. The game is not necessarily competitive but will likely involve competitive scenarios. Characters also have a race (an actual race) that limits their access to certain prison gangs and social structures.

boardgame.name: The Ghost and the Peddler (5E)
boardgame.description:
Publisher blurb:

The Ghost and the Peddler is a short adventure for three to five characters of level 3 to 5. You can play it any time the PCs need to travel through scarcely populated land for a few days.

Jack Flanagan is an apothecary traveling around the world to help those in need. Ever since his father died, Jack has felt unusually busy. The people around him experience strange accidents and suffer from unlikely diseases and parasites. Jack believes the ghost of his father is haunting him.

Will your PCs be unfortunate enough to meet Jack and travel with him?
